##

- Key: both [+]{.red} _and_ [-]{.red} are caused by technology

- Innovations have [helped]{.red} so much...

- But: from climate change to social media: malaise

- Questions:

    - Why is [bad technology]{.red} succeeding?
    
    - Why is [good technology]{.red} too often struggling?
    
    - Can we make our societies more [sustainable]{.red}?
    
    - What kind of [policies]{.red} are needed?


## Welcome!

The [(international) politics]{.red} of [technology]{.red} and [sustainability]{.red}

- Draws on ~15yrs of [policy]{.red}+[research]{.red} experience

- Substance during regular classes

    - learn about the role of [technology]{.blue} in our [societies]{.blue}
    
    - develop a sophisticated understanding of [sustainability]{.blue}
    
    - [politics]{.blue} behind this + how to design [public policies]{.blue}
    
- Skills during workshops
  
    - [analyze]{.blue} and [report]{.blue} real data for policymaking

    - develop your [problem-solving skills]{.blue}
    
::: {.notes}
New course!
:::

## Concretely

Semester divided in 3 parts

1. Welfare, technology, and sustainable development

2. Politics of sustainable technology

3. Big picture: challenges ahead

. . .

Lectures

- Theory

- Case studies

- Policy solutions


## Requirements

- Midterm: 30%. In class. 

- Research report: 

    - Analyze real US survey data to find out who is willing to adopt clean technology.

    - 40%. Due on 4/21.

* Policy report: 

    - Scientific literature review + policy recommendations on a problem connected to technology adoption. 

    - 30%. Due on 4/21.


## Rules

- (Respectful) engagement - lots of opportunities!

- Readings: multi-disciplinary, technical, online

- Attendance is mandatory but not checked

- COVID policy

- Canvas/webpage: syllabus, slides, assignments

- Office hours

- [Communication]{.red} is key (grades, etc.)
